threads.com: I've always used Expedia for flights, hotels, rental cars, etc. It hadn't even occured to me that there may be a different way to go about traveling. Is there another method that you guys use to book your stuff instead of using Expedia (or one of its competitors)?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Skyscanner is a great place to start. It shows a ton of airlines. From LAX, I found $540 to Switzerland on Swiss Air in January for a ski trip.

I also check Lufthansa and Alaska Airlines. They both have special landing pages for any deals they have going. I got a flight to Munich for $500 on Lufthansa last summer. Out of LAX, that's pretty much as cheap as it ever gets for a direct flight on a good reputable airline.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Use any site you want, but at the very least take the time to compare prices. I've had instances where the prices on third-party websites were exactly the same as booking directly, or just marginally cheaper. I don't bother booking third-party unless I can save a significant amount of money.
It's generally less of a headache to book directly, because it holds the airline/hotel/etc. accountable when something goes wrong. If you book with Expedia or some other site, they'll pass the buck on you. The airline/hotel will tell you to take it up with Expedia, then Expedia will tell you to take it up with the airline/hotel.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I normally use those kinds of sites as a starting point. Even if I don't actually book anything, I can still see what my options are. They are super-handy as I can find flight options that I never would've considered, and they're even more useful for accommodation because I know jack shit except for a few major hotel brands.

It won't amount to anything. I just got back from Kifisia which should have had amazing bike lanes. The problem is that the sidewalk on the opposite side of the street was so bad -- so that left with no better choice pedestrians just took over the rather nice bike lanes.

Korinthos by where my uncle lives has some pretty nice bike lanes as well, regardless almost no one uses them.

Patras used to have a very nice bike rental network -- no one used them and I figure the whole system is useless or abandoned by now.

Another thing is that if bike lanes don't lead to anything, they are not useful. Further Athens is just a lost cause, I think the civic mentality and infrastructure is so bad that the city is a write-off. Outside of Thessaly, Greeks generally won't bike. Probably less Greeks bike than Americans, one of the least cycling nations.

I think it is because Greek youth especially and Greek people in general don't want to be seen bicycling, they likely see it as only something for the poor(like Americans and many other nations). threads.name: Walking Tanzanian
threads.com:
So I'm thinking of leaving tomorrow and trek through my country, Tanzania. Any advice on cross-country walking? I'll leave my phone and everything behind. Carry a backpack and a few clothes and some things to lie on and cover myself, a container for food I buy along the way, and a 2 Litre bottle of water. I'll post a don't worry message on Twitter, and have about $2000 in my bank account(which is a lot in Tanzania) and will be withdrawing little by little at ATMs.

Why am I doing this? After my last suicide attempt life has been feeling pointless. I dropped out of university and have been blaming myself for not making the suicide work. I always believe the universe is so big, you can choose to minimize your gaze and focus on the little you can control, or expand your horizons and explore. I've done the former for so long and it hasn't left me satisfied, might as well try the latter for a change. I hope in this journey I find a reason to live, or a reason not to, but regardless, I owe myself to try.

I'm currently in Bukoba(picrel), I'm thinking of following the paved trunk roads and sleeping alongside it all the way to Dar es salaam. I'll try to stay at most 2 days without food before I consider taking a small bus to the closest town.

Anyway. Any advice on cross-country walking?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Looks like you're getting close to the edge of civilization, I wonder which way you're gonna go.
You're probably just waking up now, I hope you found a nice rock or patch of leaves to sleep.

Day 7: Today. Walked 16km to Nyakanazi. Actually very lively town. Got a room. Gathered the courage to ask someone where I can get a hooker. Fucked a hooker. Lol. for 10,000 TSh (about $4.2). Terrible experience.

Although... I got hurt on the way here(stepped on a nail. Disinfected it with Iodine Tincture, but I think I'll be taking buses from now on. I think I'll take a bus to Kigoma which is 200km+ and I don't think I have the patience or commitment to walk there. Will be updating you thusly. Or maybe I'll walk around when i get there.

>>2361842
Oslo -> Bergen via rail is one of the world’s great train journeys. Flying from Bergen to Lofoten directly (via Bodø) is a good onward step. You seem too retarded to consider driving the length of Norway in winter but Lofoten is generally ok. You can land at svolvær or leknes and hire a car. Narvik also gets flights but is a bit of a drive to get to Lofoten from there.

To see the northern lights in Lofoten you look north at night. If there are no clouds and there is activity you’ll see them. Getting darkness is easy and you’ll see the stars like never before. If you want an app there is an entire subculture of profound autists who obsess about auroras, use one of theirs. you can also just use your eyes.

You will need boots and also grips for the ice. If you’ve seen the new grand tour on bezosvision the start of it was filmed in Lofoten in winter. You’ll be fine if you prepare for it.

>Got any good suggestions?
My taste is all over the place, a mix of artsy/high literature stuff and trash. Like others, I often like to read novels set in places in or near where I am going. I read Burgess’s Malayan Trilogy while in Southeast Asia (got a used paperback edition in a single volume; a lot of my books are secondhand paperbacks, and some of my favorite trashiest ones can be found in dollar bins at used bookstores), and also Orwell’s Burmese Days (although I think I bought that new at a bookstore in Thailand).

I believe I first discovered the work of the extremely prolific pulp novelist Edward S. Aarons being given away on a hotel bookshelf in Laos; he wrote dozens of spy thrillers set in exotic locales from the 1950s-1970s, and his descriptions of these settings are actually excellent, although the books are mostly at least a little stupid. Similar but much lower-quality (and first found by me on the same bookshelf) are the KILLMASTER series of novels written by a committee calling itself Nick Carter, the name of the protagonist, a sort of a low-budget, American James Bond type.

I also read most of Haruki Murakami’s novels on airplanes, back in the serious literature column. 1Q84 might be my favorite but they’re all interesting. His memoirs about running are, however, really boring.

Can we do a road-trip thread for lesser known towns and cities? I'm looking for some new ideas for an epic road-trip, US or Europe.

One of the best roadtrips Ive ever done was in Colorado. We did Durango to Ouray and then Telluride. All three towns are amazing in the winter. I didn't expect much from Durango, but the ski resort there is shockingly good. We ate at two really fucking great bars on the main street. We should have stayed another night in Ouray just for the hotsprings. One night wasn't enough. And Telluride is the best ski resort Ive ever been to in the US. The town is expensive, but worth every penny. It's also one of the most beautiful drives Ive ever done in my life through the mountains. Ive been dying to go back and explore the waterfalls and rivers in the summer.

If you do it in the winter, you need snow chains for damn sure.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2361578
A solo road trip is a pretty depressing activity. You don't have friends who would go with you?

One of my favorite roadtrips is to drive up the 395 in California in the summer and take the back route into Yosemite National Park. You drive right at the base of the Sierra Mountain Range for most of the trip. You pass right by the tallest Mountain in the continental US, Mount Whitney. You go through a couple Indian reservations, past lakes, and a few ancient volcanic fields. The towns alog the way are really weird. Bishop has Erick Schat's bakery, probably the best bakery in the US. The 120 route into the back entrance of Yosemite is so beautiful that it's nearly indescribable. It's redwood forests, glaciers, pristine lakes, rivers, granite domes, waterfalls and meadows. It's my favorite drive in the US.

last_replies.com: Another epic rooadtrip is Salt Lake City Utah to Cody Wyoming. You take the route through Lava Hot Springs Idaho and then through Jackson Hole, then Yellowstone National Park and out the east entrance to Cody Wyoming. It's closed in the winter, so you have to do this one in the summer. And don't even attempt Yellowstone on a weekend. The crowds are insane. But God damn is it an epic drive. So much shit to see and do. You can stop in Lava Hot Springs and tube down a river that's fed from Hot Springs. It's like 80 degrees in the water all year. Lots of cool dive bars there too. White water rafting in Jackson, Yellowstone National Park, The Tetons, go to rodeo in Cody, eat roadside buffalo burgers, mountainbike in teton village, hit up park city utah, see the crazy mormon shit in temple square, etc etc. The whole drive is through epic mountains.

Hi /trv/

I'm going to travel the world and I don't have any money.

I've backpacking and hitchhiked the US and EU and been through some rough spots so I can handle myself while traveling. What's different now is I've learned I don't like cities and its people very much, and want to stick to forests, mountains, trails, and small towns. I think my new form of travel is PCT-esque; I'll follow mountain ranges and trails and skip into town to resupply while occasionally making stops at interesting cities or landmarks by hitching rides or local transport. What's different now is I don't plan on stopping either; this is the life I want and I want to keep going until I decide otherwise.

I have all the equipment I need and most of the know-how but I'm missing some key pieces, especially when traveling through foreign countries.
1) How do I find free (or REALLY cheap) accommodation while traveling? Camping in the woods is a non-issue for me. The occasional shower and warm bed is all I need to keep going. Finding accommodation has been a really big problem for me in large towns and cities because there aren't any camping spots and prices are expensive. This is the thing I'm most worried about.
2) Acquiring shelf-stable food. In my experience, walking into a restaurant and telling the waitress you're traveling the world and would like some free food often works. It doesn't work at a supermarket when all you need is two jars of peanut butter. How do I get food that'll keep me going for 2-3 days while hiking without money or working, ideally?
3) Safe havens when sick or injured. Occasionally I'll get sick or injured while traveling and just need a place to stay to recover. Where do I go?
4) Making money while traveling. I really don't care for money and if I have to work I want to work as little as possible. What kind of work should I be looking out for that a foreigner can do? Does busking work in foreign countries?

thanks yo

cont. in comments

additional reference: I've traveling before in foreign countries but that was traveling moreso traditionally. I was going city to city, had savings, and expected to stop when money ran out.

Now I want to hike mountains, forests, deserts in distant lands and I don't want to stop.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2361892
Brah these questions are all very much country-specific. It would help to know your intended route. I'll try to answer some, as I lived this life a lot when I was younger.
>Where to stay for cheap in cities
Simple answer is don't go to cities. If I have to overnight in an urban sprawl I go to the busiest area, huddle up in a doorway, and get maybe 1 or 2 hours of sleep. Not ideal. Other times I've paid for transport to take me to the airport, and slept there.
>Free food
If you socialize with people, you tend to get fed. How exactly depends on what country. In poor countries, dudes will just take you home and feed you. In my experience in Europe, between snacks people would buy me, foraging wild food, and dumpster diving at gas stations, I ate pretty well. And I wasn't even comfortable asking for handouts like you seem to be. In Asia I've hardly ever been offered food, dunno why.
>Safe havens
People will help you out when you need help, if you're young and look like an innocent traveler. This is universal.

threads.com:
Thought some of you may be interested in this as the info online is scarce and conflicting. St Catherine is in the middle of South Sinai, on Egypt's Sinai Peninsula. Busses leave once daily from Cairo's Torgamon bus station at 9:30am. My ticket was 175 Egyptian, ~9USD. Bus took exactly 7 hours, few stops along the way, more than half empty but I bought my ticket the day in advance to be safe.

The two main things to do in the town are climbing Mt Sinai (picrel) and visiting the monastery. Climbing the mountain was incredible and one of the best experiences I've had over 40+ countries. Takes about 4 hours to the top if you're relatively fit, and I got up in time for the sunset which was magical. You have to (read: have to) take a Bedouin guide up the mountain. Mine was really nice and very liberal with time, bought snacks, and took all the photos I wanted. Guide costs 450 all in, which I was happy with because he was lovely.

Monastery is interesting enough and worthwhile for the icon gallery (museum) which has a cool collection of religious iconography and an old treaty signed by Muhammad promising to protect the monastery.

Blatant deception and assorted jewry from some of the local Bedouin population is a blemish on the trip, though. Camp/accommodation owners will essentially force you to take their ludicrously priced drivers from the camp to the monastery/mountain. 350 Egyptian for a 10 minute taxi, same on the way back. The owners of the place I stayed (450 Egyptian per night, Bedouin camp style place) had a massive shouting match with some woman who was staying there because she called them a mafia. Apparently she tried to take a local cab to the monastery and they found out and demanded she pay them as well as the local taxi, lmao. Standard tourist prices and disingenuous swindling behaviour apply throughout the town, expect things to be double the price of Cairo. The local population runs everything, and they take advantage of it to the fullest extent.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Both are reasonable countries to visit. I've probably spent a year total in Mexico over business trips and I've visited Thailand on leisure. I think it all depends on your food and entertainment preferences, I really prefer Mexican cuisine its diversity and flavor profile but I prefer Thailand when it comes to nightlife and partying.

I'm biased because of my job - both countries feel comparatively safe, I've genuinely never been robbed or threatened in either country and I find that the CNN mentality of many Americans concerning safety in both countries is pretty laughable. I've been hassled more in Miami and Chicago than I have walking around Mexico City, even though I am visibly white and not a local. Shootings aren't as often as people make it out to be and the only cities I've ever heard gun shots were Denver and Johannesburg.

Latin women tend to be hotter, imo, but aren't nearly as easy as Thais, especially when it comes to the Mexicanas with more European ancestry. Also I noticed that money doesn't impress nearly the same in Mexico City - in a few neighborhoods, like Polanco and Santa Fe, the girls came from families with more money than I'll ever see in my life. In Bangkok being a middle-aged European with more than a few thousand in your bank account will be far more impressive and the girls seem to care less if you're fat or ugly.

I wish I could say to split your time and make your decision that way - a few weeks in Mexico visiting museums and restaurants in Mexico City, going to some of the smaller cities in Mexico, etc. and then going to Thailand for the rest of your time might be a great way to compare experiences.

My job involves security, btw, and I've never known directly of a foreigner getting kidnapped, despite the millions of dumb drunk tourists who visit a year. It's mostly cartel activity in the north. In Thailand you don't have to worry about getting shot as much as stabbed by a drunk Thai wanting your pocket change or the deadly traffic.

I’m the guy above who has walked Camino. First of all, I can’t urge you strongly enough to go on a long-distance hike. It’s a truly life-changing experience — it sounds like your mind is already made up, but I just hope you know that it’s a genuinely good choice.

I have only read about Shikoku a little bit online (I’m considering doing it at some point way down the road, not this decade though). There are a number of websites dedicated to the trail and its community. I’m not sure how many of them are in English as I haven’t done a ton of research yet. Google is your friend here. Before the pandemic, over 100k people a year were walking the trail, so whatever you’re wondering, someone is certain to have asked and answered already.

For the most part, though, it’s a long walk like most other long walks. Do your reading, sure, but mainly just be mentally prepared for the task of walking 500 miles.

Buy good shoes, and even better socks. Take care of your feet and they’ll take care of you. Good luck out there.

Is that pic your setup?

I would highly recommend packing cubes, especially the compression type. The compression type have double zippers, if you use the second set of zippers you can compress the clothes inside a bit to maximize space. I used to use those vacuum sealed clothing bags, but they were messier, even the vacuum bag gets air in it and starts decompressing -- plus it sucked sucking the air out at hotels without recourse to a vacuum. Now I stick with compression packing cubes. I personally have the Eagle Creek Pack It compression packing cubes and some cheaper ones that I got at TJ Maxx(US retail store).

I also use various other organizer containers for cables to charge my electronics, my electronics, for my bicycling accessories, I use some hanging toiletry organizer for my toothbrush, floss, toothpaste, etc.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I'm planning to go somewhere in late January with some of my lads. It'll be an extended weekend trip of about three nights.

In my infinite autism I have compiled a spreadsheet detailing the various destinations I've looked at. I'll explain the columns and then I'd like your opinion on what destination you think we should pick!

>TRANSPORTATION COST
This column details the estimated transportation cost per person for the trip. It includes: gas for driving to the airport, airport parking and a two-way flight ticket. The price is in euros.

>HOSTEL COST
The estimated hostel cost per night per person. I've only done some rudimentary checks on booking.com to get a feel for how much decent accommodation should cost at each destination. This then factors in to the predicted cost of the entire trip (3 nights * estimated hostel price). The price is in euros.

>RESTARURANT PRICES
I used numbeo.com to compare the average price of a cheap restaurant in each location with the price in Skopje, North Macedonia. The reason I chose Skopje is that I know how ridiculously cheap it is and that it was the first international trip I planned myself, so I use it as a benchmark. I then use the relative prices to predict the cost of the entire trip (2 meals * €5 * price factor).

>GROCERY STORE PRICES
I once again used numbeo.com to compare the prices and I chose Skopje for the aforementioned reasons. The grocery price factor then factors in to the total trip cost like this: (€2.5 * price factor). When we do our incredibly ghetto budget travelling we usually don't eat out for breakfast, so the €2.5 includes breakfast and any snacks we want to buy.

cont.
